answers.answer: Kudos to you for staying so active!!  Having a pacemaker set to 40 BPM seems unusually low.  Is there a reason the doctor has set the pacemaker at such a low rate?  Or, is it low because of the beta blocker?  I'm guessing your doctor wants optimal rate and BP control so your heart does not have to work too hard.I'm not a doctor, but it doesn't sound like your heart is coming to a grinding halt.  Talk frankly with your doctor during your next visit.  Let him/her know your concerns.

question: I was diagnosed with diabetes 2 in 2004, had a quadruple heart bypass in 2005 , recently developed bradycardia and had a pace maker set at 40 beats per minute. I usually find I have between 40 and 50 per minute. I take 25mg of atenolol daily. When I experimented for three days by taking no atenolol my heart rate went up to over 70 (but my blood pressure went from 130/70 to 150/85). I have no dizziness, breathlessness or other symptoms, and at age 74 lead an active life in politics and gardening.My question really is : is my heart grinding to a halt ?
title: Bradycardia and diabetes
